pullRequest.body:
Define predicates `Function.Even` and `Function.Odd` for functions satisfying `f (-x) = f x` resp. `f (-x) = -(f x)`, and prove some simple properties of these.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Group.EvenFunction`|389|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Even`
`+ Even.add`
`+ Even.comp_odd`
`+ Even.const`
`+ Even.const_smul`
`+ Even.left_comp`
`+ Even.mul_even`
`+ Even.mul_odd`
`+ Even.smul_even`
`+ Even.smul_odd`

`+ Odd.comp_odd`
`+ Odd.const_smul`

`+ Odd.mul_odd`

`+ Odd.smul_odd`
`+ Odd.zero`
`+ zero_of_even_and_odd`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10844453476/job/30093344528)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10844453476/job/30093345283)

Thanks!

bors d+
LGTM, just some minor questions.
LGTM, just some minor questions.

Thanks!

bors d+
Is it worth also having `EvenFun.zero`, even if it's an immediate consequence of `EvenFun.const`?
Well, it certainly can't do any harm, so I'll add it.

```suggestion
    EvenFun (f ∘ g) := by
  intro a
  rw [comp_apply, hg, hf, comp_apply]
```
This matches the style of all the proofs below.

I know it was discussed a bit on Zulip, but my preference here would be for:
```suggestion
def protected Function.Even (f : α → β) : Prop := ∀ a, f (-a) = f a
```
The Zulip discussion didn't have a big majority for either option, and on consideration I actually agree with Jireh that `Function.Even` is better, so I'll change it.
These hypotheses seem way too strong to me, but I can't really think of a more granular typeclass that would cover them.
Agreed. The "correct" assumption is that `β` be 2-torsion-free, which we can write as `IsSMulRegular β 2`, but that isn't a typeclass.
Does this work for monoids?
No, it doesn't I'm afraid: you need the relation `a + -a = 0`, and that is precisely the axiom that distinguishes an AddCommGroup from a SubtractionCommMonoid.
I think the convention is that this operation is called `smul'`, and the one below is `smul`.

Are you saying that "function • function" should be `smul'`, and "constant • function" should be `smul`? This  convention doesn't seem to be very universal. The scheme I followed, of calling the two `smul` and `const_smul`, matches up with [HasSum.const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/InfiniteSum/Module.html#HasSum.const_smul), [deriv_const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Deriv/Mul.html#deriv_const_smul), [ConcaveOn.smul_convexOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Convex/Mul.html#ConcaveOn.smul_convexOn) and its variants, etc. (There is also [Measurable.const_smul'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Group/Arithmetic.html#Measurable.const_smul') where the first argument is very definitely a constant...)

In the context of `Pi.smul` vs `Pi.smul'`, I thought the difference between `smul'` and `smul` was about the dependence of the _types_, not the values, on the variable.

> Are you saying that "function • function" should be `smul'`, and "constant • function" should be `smul`?

Yes

> matches up with [HasSum.const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/InfiniteSum/Module.html#HasSum.const_smul), [deriv_const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Deriv/Mul.html#deriv_const_smul),

These are so named because they are of the form `c • f x` instead of `c x • f x`

> [ConcaveOn.smul_convexOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Convex/Mul.html#ConcaveOn.smul_convexOn) and its variants, etc

This indeed backs up your claim that we are not consistent. Let's get @urkud to tie break?


> I thought the difference between `smul'` and `smul` was about the dependence of the types, not the values, on the variable.

I don't know what you mean here. The difference is whether the action is by scalars or by functions with the same domain.

> > matches up with [HasSum.const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/InfiniteSum/Module.html#HasSum.const_smul), [deriv_const_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Deriv/Mul.html#deriv_const_smul),
> 
> These are so named because they are of the form `c • f x` instead of `c x • f x`

... which is exactly the convention I have followed in the present PR (the lemmas immediately below the lines you highlighted).
I don't agree; there is no explicit function application in either the lines this thread is attached to or the ones below. These lemmas are only about `_ • f` not `_ • f x`.

> > I thought the difference between smul' and smul was about the dependence of the types, not the values, on the variable.
> 
> I don't know what you mean here. The difference is whether the action is by scalars or by functions with the same domain.

I mean that `Pi.smul'` allows `c x • f x` where `c` is a dependent function type, i.e. the type of `c x` depends on `x`. But of course a constant value has to have a constant type, so both differences are true and it is a matter of interpretation which is "the" difference.

Regarding "tie breaking": I don't think we have a tie to break. Searching the docs for `smul'` finds many hits, but hardly any of them fit the pattern of using `smul'` for the `c x • f x` usage and `smul` only for `c • f x`. Rather, `xxx_smul'` is used for any kind of slight variation on an existing `xxx_smul` lemma with no pattern at all as to how; whereas we have quite a lot of `const_smul` lemmas.

> I mean that `Pi.smul'` allows `c x • f x` where `c` is a dependent function type

I think the confusion here is that I'm talking about the operation that `Pi.smul'` defines, while you're talking about its implementation. I claim that the `smul'` in `Pi.smul'` means "this operation shall be called `smul' elsewhere" and not "this is the name we use for the implementation details of this instance".

I suggest Yury's input since I believe he defined this instance in the first place.

>  I claim that the smul' in Pi.smul' means "this operation shall be called `smul' elsewhere" 

And I claim that this attempt to prescribe a convention has not been followed in the subsequent evolution of the library, while the alternative convention of `smul` vs `const_smul` has a bit more traction. Actually, can you point to *any* example in Mathlib where this usage distinction has been observed?

More precisely there are 94 declarations whose name contains the string `smul'`. Of these, 29 involve `nsmul'`, `zsmul'`, or `const_smul'` so are definitely not following the alleged convention; and I sampled a selection of the rest and they didn't seem to have anything to do with function types. I have not found a single example, other than `Pi.smul'` itself, where the usage distinction you are advocating is obeyed. Meanwhile, there are 153 declarations involving `const_smul`.

Yury has confirmed (via Zulip DM's) that the naming of `Pi.smul'` was an arbitrary one-off decision, not intended to set out a convention for the rest of mathlib to follow. So I am going to regard this discussion as resolved.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/Group): define even and odd functions
